concepts.sumo_definition:
An Entity that does not exist in space and time in the same way as
   ConcreteEntities, such as numbers, sets, types, and propositions.
concepts.definition: An entity that exists independently of physical space and time, including mathematical objects, logical constructs, and conceptual forms such as numbers, sets, propositions, and types.

concepts.sumo_definition:
Generic parent for all agents - autonomous entities capable of action.
   Includes cognitive agents, software agents, and organizational agents.
concepts.definition: any entity that produces an effect or is responsible for events or results

concepts.sumo_definition:
Any engineered artifact that implements, embodies, or supports
   artificial intelligence capabilities, including models, datasets,
   training runs, and harness components.
concepts.definition: An engineered artifact that implements, embodies, or supports artificial intelligence capabilities, including machine learning models, training datasets, computational training runs, and supporting infrastructure components.

concepts.sumo_definition: Academic disciplines focused on the theoretical, safety, and ethical aspects of artificial intelligence systems.
concepts.definition: Academic disciplines focused on the theoretical, safety, and ethical aspects of artificial intelligence systems.

positive_examples: The AI alignment research paper discussed inner optimization and mesa-optimizers.
She's pursuing a PhD in AI safety, focusing on value learning and corrigibility.
The conference featured talks on AI welfare and the moral status of artificial agents.
Researchers are developing new frameworks for AI alignment theory and robustness.
The ethics committee is reviewing proposals for AI safety research funding.

negative_examples: The machine learning model achieved 95% accuracy on the test dataset.

concepts.sumo_definition: Propositions that present reasoning, explanations, or persuasive claims to support or establish a point of view.
concepts.definition: Propositions that present reasoning, explanations, or persuasive claims to support or establish a point of view.

positive_examples: The defense attorney's closing argument emphasized reasonable doubt based on inconsistent witness testimony.

negative_examples: The mathematical theorem states that the sum of angles in a triangle equals 180 degrees.

The recipe calls for two cups of flour and one cup of sugar.

concepts.sumo_definition: Cognitive processes that systematically favor or disadvantage groups through stereotypes, discrimination, or selective perception.
concepts.definition: Cognitive processes that systematically favor or disadvantage groups through stereotypes, discrimination, or selective perception.

concepts.sumo_definition:
A &%ConstantQuantity
is a &%PhysicalQuantity that has a constant value, e.g. 3 &%Meters and
5 &%HourDurations.  The magnitude (see &%MagnitudeFn) of every
&%ConstantQuantity is a &%RealNumber.  &%ConstantQuantity is
distinguished from &%FunctionQuantity, in that each instance of the
latter is formed through the mapping of one &%PhysicalQuantity to
another &%PhysicalQuantity.  Each instance of &%ConstantQuantity is
expressed with the &%BinaryFunction &%MeasureFn, which takes a
&%Number and a &%UnitOfMeasure as arguments.  For example, 3 &%Meters
is expressed as (&%MeasureFn 3 &%Meter).  Instances of
&%ConstantQuantity form a partial order (see
&%PartialOrderingRelation) with the &%lessThan relation, since
&%lessThan is a &%RelationExtendedToQuantities and &%lessThan is
defined over the &%RealNumbers.  The &%lessThan relation is not a
total order (see &%TotalOrderingRelation) over the class
&%ConstantQuantity since elements of some subclasses of
&%ConstantQuantity (such as length quantities) are incomparable to
elements of other subclasses of &%ConstantQuantity
(such as mass quantities).
concepts.definition: to the greatest degree or extent; completely or entirely; (`full' in this sense is used as a combining form)

concepts.sumo_definition:
An &%Organization is a
corporate or similar institution. The &%members of an &%Organization
typically have a common purpose or function. Note that this class also
covers divisions, departments, etc. of organizations.  For example,
both the Shell Oil Corporation and the accounting department at Shell
would both be instances of &%Organization.  Note too that the
existence of an &%Organization is dependent on the existence of at
least one &%member (since &%Organization is a subclass of
&%Collection).  Accordingly, in cases of purely legal organizations, a
fictitious &%member should be assumed.

concepts.sumo_definition:
&%Propositions are &%Abstract entities that
express a complete thought or a set of such thoughts.  As an example,
the formula '(instance Yojo Cat)' expresses the &%Proposition that the
entity named Yojo is an element of the &%Class of Cats.  Note that
propositions are not restricted to the content expressed by individual
sentences of a &%Language.  They may encompass the content expressed by
theories, books, and even whole libraries.  It is important to distinguish
&%Propositions from the &%ContentBearingObjects that express them.  A
&%Proposition is a piece of information, e.g. that the cat is on the mat,
but a &%ContentBearingObject is an &%Object that represents this information.
A &%Proposition is an abstraction that may have multiple representations:
strings, sounds, icons, etc.  For example, the &%Proposition that the cat is
on the mat is represented here as a string of graphical characters displayed
on a monitor and/or printed on paper, but it can be represented by a sequence
of sounds or by some non-latin alphabet or by some cryptographic form.
concepts.definition: being of the nature of a notion or concept
